abstract.text: The inclusive A 1,p and hadron double-spin asymmetries A π+ p , A π− p , A K+ p , A K− p measured at COMPASS (CERN SPS) in deep-inelastic scattering of a polarized muon beam off a polarized NH 3 solid target are presented.
The results have been obtained with the full statistics collected in 2007 for the longitudinal target polarization.
Proton asymmetries have been combined with the published deuteron ones.
An evaluation of the non-singlet spin-dependent structure function g NS 1 (x, Q 2 ) and its first moment, which confirms the validity of the Bjorken sum-rule, is presented.
A LO evaluation of polarized quark densities is also presented.
The use of the proton data allows to perform a full flavor separation and to extract individual helicity densities of u, d,ū,d and s quarks.
All sea quark densities are found to be compatible with zero in the full range of the measurements.

body_text.text: Introduction
New results of the COMPASS experiment at CERN on the proton spin asymmetry A 1,p and the structure function g p 1 are presented.
The data were collected during the year 2007.
We refer the reader to [1] for the description of the 160 GeV muon beam, the NH 3 polarized target and the COMPASS spectrometer.
DIS events are selected by cuts on the virtuality of the photon, Q 2 > 1 (GeV/c) 2 , and its fractional energy, 0.1 < y < 0.9.

The values of the spin-dependent structure function g p 1 (x, Q 2 ) have been combined with the published g d 1 (x, Q 2 ) ones [2] in order to evaluate the nonsinglet structure function g NS 1 (x, Q 2 ).
We also present an evaluation of the helicity quark distributions ∆u, ∆d, ∆ū, ∆d and ∆s (=∆s) which were obtained in a combined analysis of inclusive and identified hadron asymmetries.
Both deuteron [3] and proton data have been used.
In addition to the kinematic cuts mentioned above, for hadron tracks coming from the primary vertex the cut z > 0.2 is applied to select the current fragmentation region.
To avoid ambiguities between secondary muons and the scattered muon we demand z < 0.85.
Hadrons are identified as pions or kaons by the RICH detector which limits their momenta to the range 10 < p < 50 GeV/c.
The total statistics of samples obtained with the proton target for the inclusive, π + (π − ) and K + (K − ) events after all cuts is 92.5, 13.3 (11.8) and 3.9 (2.6) million events, respectively.

An evaluation of the first moment of g NS 1 (x) provides a new test of the Bjorken sum rule.
This sum rule first derived using current algebra is considered as a fundamental result of QCD.
The Q 2 dependence of g NS 1 is decoupled from the evolution of ∆Σ and ∆G.

Consequently a fit of the Q 2 evolution of g NS 1 requires only a small number of parameters to describe the shape of ∆q 3 (x) at some reference Q 2 and its integral, which is proportional to the ratio g A /g V of the axial and vector coupling constants.

The comparison of the fitted value of this ratio with the one derived from neutron β decay (|g A /g V | = 1.2695 ± 0.0029 [6]) provides a test of the Bjorken sum rule, free of systematic errors arising from uncertainties on ∆G.

The dominant systematic error is due to the uncertainty of 5% on the beam polarisation, which translates directly into a 5% error on g A /g V (i.e.±0.065).
The other contributions due to P T and f are ±0.041 for A 1,d and ±0.056 for A p 1 .

The 10 measured asymmetries (see Eq. 6) form a linear system of equations with 5 unknowns ∆u, ∆d, ∆ū, ∆d and ∆s.
The system is solved by a least-square fit independently in each x-bin.
Only statistical errors were used in the fit and correlations between asymmetries were taken into account.
A symmetry of the polarized strange sea is assumed, ∆s ≡ ∆s.
In principle ∆s and ∆s could both be extracted from the charged kaon asymmetries A K+ p,d and A K− p,d but in view of the precision of the data, they are assumed to be equal.
All asymmetries are also assumed to be independent of Q 2 .
In this way the resulting PDFs are obtained at a common Q 2 fixed to 3 (GeV/c) 2 .
The quark helicity distributions, obtained with the DSS fragmentation functions, are shown as a function of x with their statistical and systematic errors in Fig. 4.
The curves obtained with the LO DNS [10] parametrization of polarized PDFs are also shown.
The ∆u, ∆d, ∆ū, ∆d curves from the DNS parametrization fit well our points.
However one can see a discrepancy in the ∆s graph.
The shape of the x∆s curve of DNS is quite typical for QCD fits of g 1 (x, Q 2 ) data, with a minimum in the medium x region (x ≈ 0.2).
The SIDIS measurements of COMPASS (it is also true for HERMES) do not support this behavior, at least not with the DSS fragmentation functions.
More details on the distribution ∆s(x) are given in Ref.
The present analysis including the 2007 proton data confirms the results obtained with the deuteron data and reduces significantly the statistical errors.
In the most recent global fit of polarized PDFs, DSSV [11], a more flexible parametrization for the strange quark distribution was adopted.
This fit includes HER-MES data and therefore provides a positive strange polarization at large x and a negative one at small x.
A full comparison to our points obtained at LO is not possible because the parametrization is provided at NLO only.

A sizable flavor asymmetry between the unpolarized up and down sea quark distributions (ū(x)−d(x) < 0 ) is a well established experimental fact since more than ten years (see for instance [12] and references therein).
It has inspired a large theoretical activity and lead to various nonperturbative models which also naturally predict a flavor asymmetry for the helicity densities of the light sea (∆ū − ∆d 0).
Most of the models, like Pauliblocking models, instanton model, chiral quark soliton model, statistical models (see review [13] and references therein), predict a positive value of ∆ū−∆d.
The meson cloud models are the only ones which predict a ∆ū−∆d small in absolute value but with a negative sign.
Only experimental measurements can provide a test of these predictions.
The x distribution of ∆ū−∆d calculated with the PDFs obtained in the LO fit described above is shown in Fig. 5.
One should note that the systematics error does not include the uncertainty from the FF parametrization since it was not provided by DSS authors.
A one-sigma effect in a narrower x range is also claimed by HERMES: 0.3 0.023 (∆ū − ∆d)dx = 0.048 ± 0.057(stat) ± 0.028(syst).
The prediction of the DNS parametrization is shown in Fig. 5.

One can notice a remarkable agreement of COMPASS measurements with the DNS curve which is driven by the measurements of HERMES, the only other experiment which measured asymmetries of identified hadrons on a proton target.
Summary
A first COMPASS measurement of inclusive and identified hadron spin asymmetries with a proton target has been presented.
These asymmetries were included into a combined analysis together with the previously published deuteron ones.
An evaluation of the nonsinglet spin-dependent structure function g NS 1 (x, Q 2 ) was presented.
The first moment of this function confirms the validity of the Bjorken sum-rule with better than one σ precision.
A LO evaluation of polarized quark densities was also presented.
The use of the proton in addition to deuteron data allowed to extract a full set of polarized PDFs ∆u, ∆d, ∆ū, ∆d and ∆s (=∆s).
All sea quark densities are found to be compatible with zero in the full range of measurements.
However the discrepancy in a shape of ∆s(x) with the one obtained in a typical global QCD fit was discovered.
A small excess of ∆ū with respect to ∆d was observed.
